Authors:
Chanintorn Doungsa-ard, Alistair Ross McTaggart, Roger G.
Shivas, Andrew D.W. Geering
Title:
The diversity of Uromycladium tepperianum on Acacia spp. in
Australia
Journal: Persoonia: Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution of Fungi
Keywords:
Cryptic species, Uromycladium, Pileolariaceae,
Pucciniales, systematic, taxonomy
Abstract:
Uromycladium tepperianum sensu lato is a common and
widespread rust that produces galls on over a hundred species of Acacia
as well as the closely related genera Falcataria and Paraserianthes.
This study investigated the phylogenetic relationships between 65
specimens of U. tepperianum sensu lato with a combined morphological and
molecular approach. Molecular phylogenetic analyses were based on a
combined dataset of the Small Subunit, the Internal transcribed Spacer
and the Large Subunit regions of nuclear ribosomal DNA, and the
mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit 3. The recovered phylogenetic
hypothesis indicated that U. tepperianum sensu stricto occurs on ‘A.
bivenosa group’ host species, which was supported by morphological data.
A provisional epitype of U. tepperianum on A. ligulata is designated to
create a stable taxonomy for the application of this widespread rust
species. Fourteen new provisional species of Uromycladium are described
from the U. tepperianum species complex based on host preference,
morphology and phylogenetic concordance.
